DataElement.preferredName: Low Grade Glioma Supratentorial Localization Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The named locations of a grade I or grade II glioma arising from the  intracranial venous sinus that lies in a superior and midline location above the interhemispheric fissure along the superior border of the falx cerebri of the brain.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma._An intracranial venous sinus that lies in a superior and midline location above the interhemispheric fissure along the superior border of the falx cerebri of the brain. The sinus receives blood from the cerebral veins and drains posteriorly into the lateral sinuses of the brain, which in turn drain into the internal jugular veins.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma.

Concepts.definition: A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma.

Property.preferredDefinition: An intracranial venous sinus that lies in a superior and midline location above the interhemispheric fissure along the superior border of the falx cerebri of the brain. The sinus receives blood from the cerebral veins and drains posteriorly into the lateral sinuses of the brain, which in turn drain into the internal jugular veins.

Concepts.definition: An intracranial venous sinus that lies in a superior and midline location above the interhemispheric fissure along the superior border of the falx cerebri of the brain. The sinus receives blood from the cerebral veins and drains posteriorly into the lateral sinuses of the brain, which in turn drain into the internal jugular veins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

PermissibleValues.value: Unknown: Could not be determined or unsure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

Concepts.definition: An indication that something is indeterminate or unknown.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The outer layer of the cerebrum composed of neurons and unmyelinated nerve fibers.  It is responsible for memory, attention, consciousness and other high mental functions.

Concepts.definition: The outer layer of the cerebrum composed of neurons and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It is responsible for memory, attention, consciousness and other higher levels of mental function.

PermissibleValues.value: Deep Gray (e.g. Basal ganglia or Thalamus)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The gray matter that includes the basal ganglia and/or thalamus.

Concepts.definition: The gray matter that includes the basal ganglia and/or thalamus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The nerve tissue forming the bulk of the deep parts of the brain and the superficial parts of the spinal cord.  It is composed of nerve cell processes, i.e. extensions (axons), which connect various grey matter areas of the brain to each other and carry nerve impulses to and from the nerve cell bodies within the central nervous system (neurons).  Cerebral and spinal white matter does not contain dendrites.  White matter is distinguished in that it is composed of axonal nerve fibers covered by a myelin sheath.

Concepts.definition: The nerve tissue forming the bulk of the deep parts of the brain and the superficial parts of the spinal cord. It is composed of nerve cell processes, i.e. extensions (axons), which connect various grey matter areas of the brain to each other and carry nerve impulses to and from the nerve cell bodies within the central nervous system (neurons). Cerebral and spinal white matter does not contain dendrites. White matter is distinguished in that it is composed of axonal nerve fibers covered by a myelin sheath.
